thread.title: Strong US growth paves way for September interest rate hike from the Federal Reserve
thread.title_full: Strong US growth paves way for September interest rate hike from the Federal Reserve

title: Strong US growth paves way for September interest rate hike from the Federal Reserve
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Jul 30, 2015, 14:57 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 33 mins Strong US growth paves way for September interest rate hike from the Federal Reserve By Peter Spence | Telegraph â€“ 9 minutes ago Print 
The US central bank may raise its rates sooner than previously expected 
The US economy appeared in stronger shape on the second quarter, as economists revised away much of the downturn suffered at the beginning of the year. 
The Bureau of Economic Analysis said that GDP rose at an annualised pace of 2.3pc in the second quarter of the year, slightly below the 2.5pc expected by analysts. 
But revisions to earlier data meant that the growth picture was brighter overall, priming the US economy for its first increase in interest rates in more than nine years. 
A previous estimate of a contraction in the first quarter was wiped out by statisticians. They now believe that GDP rose by 0.6pc in the period at an annualised rate, higher than the 0.2pc fall pencilled in before. 
Federal Reserve chairman Janet Yellen (Photo: REUTERS/Mike Theiler) 
The data came as the Federal Reserve mulls raising its key policy rate towards the end of the year. 
A statement released on Wednesday indicated that the strength of economic data would determine whether policymakers opted to increase that rate in September or December. 
Jeremy Cook, of currency firm World First, said: "Failing a disaster in the next few job market reports, you can pencil in that September rate rise now." 
Further revisions to growth data for the years from 2011 to 2014 left the US's performance looking markedly worse, particularly in 2013. 
James Knightley, of ING, said: "This may lead some at the Fed to conclude that the US may have marginally more spare capacity than previously thought, which would reduce the need for an imminent rate rise." 
"However, given the fairly strong rhetoric from officials and the focus on the labour data we doubt that it would block a September hike", he said."
